Authors:
Andr√© V. L. Freitas, Nicolas Chazot, Keith R Willmott,
Gerardo Lamas, Florence Piron-Prunier, Carlos F Arias, Jim Mallet, Donna
Lisa De-Silva, Marianne Elias
Title:
Renewed diversification following Miocene landscape turnover
in a Neotropical butterfly radiation
Keywords:
Neotropics, phylogeny, diversification, biogeography,
Andes, Pebas system, Western-Andean Portal, Ithomiini, butterflies
Abstract:
The landscape of the Neotropical region has undergone
dynamic evolution throughout the Miocene, with the extensive Pebas
wetland occupying western Amazonia between 23 and ~10 My ago and the
continuous uplift of the Andes mountains. These complex dynamics and
interactions between the Andes and Amazonia have likely had a major
influence on the trajectory of Neotropical biodiversity, but evidence
from time-calibrated phylogenies of groups that diversified during this
period are lacking. We investigate the role of these landscape
transformations on the dynamics of diversification in the Neotropical
region using a 26 My-old endemic butterfly radiation. We generated one
of the most comprehensive time-calibrated molecular phylogenies of a
large clade of Neotropical insects, the butterfly tribe Ithomiini,
comprising 340 species (87% of extant species) and spanning 26 My of
diversification. We applied a large array of birth-death models and
historical biogeography estimations to assess the dynamics of
diversification and biotic interchanges, especially at the
Amazonia/Andes interface. Our results suggest that the Amazonian Pebas
wetland system played a major role in the timing and geography of
diversification of Ithomiini, by constraining dispersal and
diversification in the Amazon basin until ~10 My ago. During the Pebas
wetland period Ithomiini diversification mostly took place in the Andes,
where terrestrial habitats where not affected. An explosion of
interchanges with Amazonia and with the Northern Andes accompanied the
demise of the Pebas system (11-8 My ago), and was followed by local
diversification in those areas, which led to a substantial renewal of
diversification. While many studies on Neotropical diversity have
focused only on the Andes, we show that it is the waxing and waning of
the Pebas mega-wetland, interacting with Andean uplift, that have
determined the timing and patterns of regional interchanges and
diversification in Ithomiini.
